Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps L: STEM-Packs - Supporting STEM Learning Through Literature

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Through the NSF Innovation Corps for Learning Program (I-Corps L), this project will develop ways to increase the scale and impact of Summer Reading Club resources called STEM Packs that integrate STEM content into reading club themes. STEM Packs are resources containing materials and professional development modules for incorporating Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics into annually conducted Summer Reading Clubs in libraries. The project takes advantage of already nationally established and themed Summer Reading Club programming, and its popularity, as an ideal resource introduction target. The STEM Packs are stackable for multi-session use by a library staff that, in general, does not have the requisite knowledge in STEM content or pedagogy to develop its own tools for effective engagement with young patrons. Children's librarians and their volunteers who conduct Summer Reading Club are often proficient and entertaining storytellers, or have access to storytellers, but they require capacity-building and resources to embed STEM content into reading development. This project will increase the impact of STEM Packs by developing ways of sustaining wider use of these materials on a national basis.

A STEM Pack is comprised of one piece of children's literature and accompanying STEM inquiry-based learning activities that directly connect to the theme and main ideas featured in the children's literature and to the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS)/Common Core State Standards (CCSS). STEM Packs are designed: (1) to incorporate STEM learning with reading and storytelling practices already in place for Summer Reading Club, primarily for pre-Kindergarten to 8th grade level; (2) to lead to stackable STEM Packs, which provide just-in time resources for librarians, volunteers, and parents to support students in connecting fiction and non-fiction literature to learning STEM concepts; (3) to continue a pilot foundation integrating Next Generation Science Standards and Common Core State Standards in Mathematics and English Language Arts into summer reading; (4) to serve to scale to statewide and national scope; (5) to help bridge the three-month gap between scholastic or formal-learning semesters, and to accomplish this in a way that is consistent with uniform standards for learning for all children. A further objective is to widely elevate the role of library in community to the role of partnership with schools: to show how the informal educational function of the library can be elevated to become part of a whole-year scholastic learning experience.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Through the I-Corps L Grant, the Allegheny Intermediate Unit Math & Science Collaborative, in partnership with the Westmoreland Library Network, refined the development of STORYTIME STEM-PACKS, resources that integrate STEM activities with children’s literature for use during Summer Reading Club in public libraries. The project leaders conducted 124 interviews with children’s librarians, library directors, library donors, decision makers (elected and unelected), Head Start teachers, K-12 teachers and administrators, and parents.  They were asked about their perspectives on STEM learning; they were also asked about what kind of resources and support would help to advance children’s STEM learning, and what obstacles they face as educators or supporters of STEM learning. Analyzing the results of the interviews led to focusing of the features of STORYTIME STEM-PACKS and associated professional development, so that both most effectively can help adults with little or no STEM background to support children in STEM learning. The interviews also made us aware that, in addition to public libraries, there was interest in STORYTIME STEM-PACKS by K-12 educators and parents, expanding a possible market for this product. Businesses and donors were in favor of bringing these resources into public libraries to enhance STEM programming. All stakeholders, as part of a STEM Ecosystem, were also interested in forging closer relationships with each other, working together to strengthen STEM learning for young children. 

STORYTIME STEM-PACKS consist of one piece of children’s literature each and accompanying STEM learning activities that directly connect to the theme and main ideas featured in the piece of children’s literature, as well as to Next Generation Science Standards and Common Core Math Standards. They are easy to use, just-in-time resources that enable any educator to incorporate STEM concepts into children’s programming from PreK- 3 with minimal preparation time. With these features they enable adults without formal STEM training to effectively facilitate STEM learning for young children in school settings as well as in informal settings, such as public libraries. By providing one vehicle to bring effective standards-based STEM programming to public libraries, they serve to address the summer slide, with library programming creating a bridge for STEM learning over the summer.

In STORYTIME STEM-PACKS the story is used to create a context and jump-off point for the STEM activity; the story motivates children to engage in STEM learning, becoming actors in the story. On the other side, children, who are drawn to hands-on learning and STEM are being provided with an alternative entry point to reading, as they experience the story as part of the activity. As children are engaged in STORYTIME STEM-PACKS, they are provided with opportunities to engage and solve problems. They use critical thinking, collaborate and communicate. They build persistence, and they experience that there are multiple ways to solve a problem, and that failure is a part of the process, necessary for learning.

With their emphasis on standards and alignment to STEM concepts, STORYTIME STEM-PACKS contribute to very early STEM workforce development. The facilitator guide and professional development provided with STORYTIME STEM-PACKS build capacity for that for children’s librarians, library directors, and educators. From our surveys we learned that participating library staff and educators feel more confident and better prepared to facilitate STEM-activities with children. From informal discussions and feedback we learned that this comfort level is not confined to STORYTIME STEM-PACKS, but also extends to tackling STEM in general, encouraging librarians and educators to also seek out other STEM resources, or go back and use STEM materials that have previously been underutilized.

This project has so far put thirty-three STORYTIME STEM-PACKS into public libraries and schools. It is well positioned to greatly expand these numbers, making quality STEM resources widely available to children’s librarians and primary teachers.  In summary, the project team set out to accomplish the following goals, and it did:

(1)  Refine a STEM-learning product (now named STORYTIME STEM-PACKS) for public libraries, inclusive of professional development (PD) and based on informed value propositions for various stakeholders and customers (a goal informed by the I-CORP L experience).

(2)  Establish a workable commercialization plan for our educational innovation (STORYITME STEM-PACKS, with PD) across a broader range of public libraries as well as K-12 schools, regionally (Southwest Pennsylvania), statewide, and nationally. 

(3)   Incorporate STEM learning in children’s programming in public libraries, informed by curriculum grade-level standards.

(4) Bridge grade-level learning during the otherwise low-STEM-content, out-of-school summer months and at other intervals.

(5) Engage volunteers and family members in the learning so that children and their families realize enrichment in both the library and home settings.

To learn more about STORYTIME STEM-PACKS and our work, please visit us at www.storytimestem.com and http://www.aiumsc.net/
